etymology.description: Pictogram: sugarcane with full stems and an open mouth; originally for 蔗 (“sugarcane”) or 煮 (“to boil”); later phonetically loaned for abstract meanings. Top 耂 is unrelated to 老; a variant with an extra 丶 reflects Shuowen’s 白 analysis.
etymology.interpretation: Originally a drawing of sugarcane with a mouth at the base, it depicted either “sugarcane” or “to boil.” The form was later borrowed for abstract, agentive/nominalizing use, yielding meanings like “person; one who” seen in compounds such as 作者 and 读者.

examples.chinese: 读者喜欢这本书(讀者喜歡這本書)。
他是一位勤奋的研究者(他是一位勤奮的研究者)。
examples.pinyin: Tā shì yī wèi qínfèn de yánjiūzhě.

examples.chinese: 受害者已经报警(受害者已經報警)。
examples.english: The victim has already called the police.
